Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: AVATOL - Next Generation Phenomics for the Tree of Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
Darwin's theory of evolution explained that millions of species are related, and dealt biologists and paleontologists the enormous challenge of discovering the branching pattern of the Tree of Life. Work on this great challenge is producing a map of species-relatedness through Earth history, and answering questions such as "what is the closest relative of a species?" and "what species make important products?" To do this scientists draw on all heritable features, including genotypes (e.g., DNA) and phenotypes (e.g., anatomy). Studying phenotypes, however, has remained complicated and slow, because it has not been revolutionized by computer science and engineering innovations.

A team of biologists, computer scientists, and paleontologists will extend and adapt methods from computer vision, machine learning, crowd-sourcing and natural language processing to enable rapid and automated study of phenotypes for the Tree of Life on a vast scale. The three-year goal is to release large phenomic datasets built using new methods, and to provide the public and scientific community with tools for future work. Planned is the training of teachers and students (kindergarten - postdoctoral levels) and the engagement of "citizen scientists." Enormous phenomic datasets, many with images, will fill an important public interest in biodiversity and the fossil record.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Science magazine has identified the construction of the Tree of Life (the genealogy of living and extinct species) as one of the top challenges for biology in the 21st century.  To build this Tree, scientists must collect data on all heritable features – genotypes (e.g., DNA sequences) and phenotypes (e.g., anatomy, behavior, physiology).  The task is very challenging because there may be as many as 100 million living species on Earth, as well as hundreds of thousands of fossil species.  Only a small portion of these species have been identified and named, much less studied to assess where they fit on the Tree of Life (phylogeny).

An important research challenge is that the collection of data on phenotypes has lagged behind the collection of data on genotypes.  While new innovations have greatly advanced the identification and storage of gene data, the study of comparative phenotypes remains a slow process and one that has changed little in decades.  Advances in computer science and engineering have the potential to change this situation.  As part of this sponsored research, we assembled an interdisciplinary team of biologists, paleontologists, computer scientists, and software developers to take up the challenge of adapting modern computer science and engineering innovations to the collection of phenotypic data for tree-building.

To this end, we pursued approaches in Crowd Sourcing, Computer Vision, and Natural Language Processing to improve collection of phenotypic data, and we developed new software packages to do this.  Natural Language Processing aims to extract data from legacy literature such that the data can be directly read by a computer.  Computer Vision and Crowd Sourcing techniques aim to capture new data on both partially described and undescribed species by using digital images. 

Intellectual Merit:  Each of the three approaches produced promising results to advance the collection of data on phenotypes.  As described our peer-reviewed research paper published in Systematic Biology as part of this grant, we discovered that citizen scientists, specifically undergraduate biology students, could identify phenotypic traits with a high degree of success if they were provided with example images curated by experts.  In the paper we described new statistical methods to combine the work of experts and nonexperts that has the potential to save research time if further developed.  We released for public use a new web-based crowd sourcing software package called The Evolution Project, and released eight scientifically curated datasets with hundreds of new species images on MorphoBank.org.  Using computer vision algorithms we were able to build software to train computers to identify common parts on species (for example, to read a digital image and identify a mammal tooth).  Finally, we were also able to extract from classic text form information on the condition of certain features in species (for example, that a leaf contained a particular venation structure).  We anticipate that this experimental work will be a foundation for more broadly applied innovations in the collection of phenotypic data.  Ready access to curated information on phenotypes has the potential to impact other fields such as horticulture, drug-discovery, fisheries, and geosciences.

Broader Impact:  Over the course of this research we trained several postdoctoral associates and graduate students, we introduced undergraduates and high school students to interdisciplinary research, and we released new datasets to the public.  We also contributed an important new test case on citizen science that may be an example to follow when identifying ways for the public to collaborate with scientists.  Datasets that have been released to the public provide an important new resource for anyone studying a range of living and fossil species.Several of the postdoctoral associates that we trained and mentored come from populations that are underrepresented in science.  Three of these Ph.D.s have gone on to find permanent jobs in scientific fields following this project.
